subject: Sleep
title: Elephants Sleep Standing Up
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Elephants Sleep Standing Up.

hook.text: Wild elephants sleep only two hours per night, the shortest of any mammal. And they often sleep standing up.

buildup.text: Their massive body size makes lying down risky. Getting up quickly to escape predators is difficult for a five-ton animal.

discovery.text: They enter REM sleep only when they lie down, which happens just every three to four days.

twist.text: Captive elephants sleep six or more hours because they have no predators, suggesting wild sleep is survival-limited.

climax.text: Despite minimal sleep, elephants show complex cognition, empathy, and memory, challenging our assumptions about sleep need.

punchline.text: Elephants never forget, even on two hours of sleep.

quiz.question: How often do wild elephants enter REM sleep?
options: Every three to four days when they lie down
